If you make any sort of mistake moving forward from the early years, you're likely going to die. And, like, the startups can die. Michael Siebel, the guy who came after him, talked about how when startups, every year that they survive, they're that much closer to long term success, because every year that you're still alive is evidence that you're not dead and thus have the chance of being a more successful company. So I think the lean startup does a great job talking about, like, here's an example. When you're kind of going to your first conference, right? Don't buy 100 t shirts to distribute. No one's ever heard of you. No one wants the t shirt with your name on it. So it might make sense to, hey, the first couple of times, maybe get like, five t shirts. Take a lean approach to the things that you, that you're trying to sort of promote. And even, not even just swag, even from the product billing perspective, there's 100 different features you got to build. Just focus on the ones that are most, like, the biggest pain points people talk about, the most, and the smallest MVP version of it. So I think that book does a great job teaching you how to build companies in a lean way.
